header.title: WICCA 201 CORRELLIAN WICCA LESSONS FOR THE SECOND DEGREE

central_thesis: This workbook provides a broad knowledge of practical metaphysical skills and their underlying theories, serving as a comprehensive curriculum for Second Degree Clergy within the Correllian Tradition, building upon foundational First Degree lessons and offering pathways for specialization in various occult arts.

structure_content.summary: This section outlines the purpose of the Second Degree curriculum, detailing the three core classes (Wicca 201, 202, 203) and introducing the Correllian Three Degree system, including the symbolic representations and expected roles of First, Second, and Third Degree Clergy.

Explores the history, philosophy, and practical applications of Tarot cards, including detailed interpretations of the Major and Minor Arcana, and various reading spreads (One Card, Three Card, Celtic Cross, Zodiac, Yes/No).

Introduces the ancient art of reading human body features (hair, forehead, ears, eyes, nose, mouth, jaw, chin, limbs, chest, nipples, belly, hips, buttocks, thighs, knees, calves, ankles, feet, toes, soles) and moles for divining personality traits, future potential, and emotional states. It contextualizes these practices within historical and modern cultural perspectives.

Provides an overview of basic Astrological principles, including the Ptolemaic and Outer Planets, zodiacal signs, and Houses. It explains how these elements are used in chart interpretation and their allegorical significance in magical practice, contextualizing Astrology within its ancient Mesopotamian origins and Correllian philosophy.

Examines various historical and magical alphabets (Phoenician, Greek, Theban, Enochian, Malachim, Celestial, Passing the River, Nug-Soth, Daggers, Correllian) and their applications in Gematria, spellwork, and creating a magical atmosphere, emphasizing their role as tools for focused concentration and connecting to past knowledge.

Details the Pythagorean system of Numerology, focusing on the Ennead (numbers 0-9) and Master Numbers (11, 22, 33, etc.). It explains how to calculate and interpret the Numerological value of words and names to reveal inner nature and life path, tying it to the concept of Correspondences.

Discusses Pagan views on death, the journey to the Otherworld, and the roles of Spirit Guides (Beloved Ancestors) and World Walkers. It describes Near Death Experiences, trance-induced crossings, and the concept of conscious incarnation, offering practical advice for helping spirits and returning adepts.

Explores the philosophical and practical aspects of sex magic across Pagan, Hindu Tantra, Taoist, and Celtic traditions. It highlights the concept of Hierogamos (Divine Marriage) as a central element for spiritual development, union with Deity, and channeling psychic energy, contrasting Pagan views on sexuality with Book Religions.

Introduces the concept of magical calendars as tools for divination and aligning with natural energies. It covers the historical development of Western, Chinese Hsia, and Aztec calendars, and presents the Witches’ Calendar of Years for understanding calendrical astrology.

Presents an advanced Chakra system based on Peter Binder's 'Astral Physics', detailing Temporal, Existential, and Foundational Chakras, their seven levels, and associated Right and Left Companions. It emphasizes practical exercises for developing and working with these subtle energy centers.

Explores the history and contemporary understanding of Ley Lines (Dragon Lines) as Earth's energy currents. It describes different types (Yang/Yin, temporal), methods for locating them (dowsing, clairvoyance), and their application in geometric magic using various shapes (spheres, beams, tetrahedrons, pyramids, cubes, octahedrons, decahedrons, dodecahedrons, icosahedrons) and the Correllian Crystal Web.

Introduces the eight sacred Trigrams (Ba Gua) from Chinese philosophy, explaining their relation to Yin and Yang, their symbolic meanings (Heaven, Earth, Thunder, Wind, Water, Fire, Mountain, Lake), and their role as the foundation of the Yi Jing hexagrams for divination.

Discusses the organizational structure, management, and political aspects of Correllian Temples and Shrines. It defines the roles of Temple Head, Co-Head, Chief Director, Directors, Chief Cleric, and Pursuivant Priesthood, and provides guidelines for ethical interaction within the Pagan community and the wider world.

key_concepts.definition: A Wiccan tradition that follows a Three Degree system, emphasizing practical metaphysical skills and spiritual development, with a focus on integrating various occult arts.
The 22 Tarot cards dealing with spiritual themes, representing the soul's journey and containing insights into the Universe's secrets, viewed as a visual scripture.
The 56 Tarot cards dealing with mundane and personal situations, divided into four suits (Swords, Wands, Cups, Pentacles) corresponding to the Four Elements.
The art of divining personality characteristics, future potential, and present psychological/emotional states by reading the features of the human body and face.
The art of interpreting letters, words, and phrases by assigning numerical values to individual letters and summing them, used to expand upon meaning and reveal inner nature.

An ancient Greek numerological technique involving translating letters of a word or phrase into numerical equivalents and summing them, then comparing results between different words to find hidden metaphysical correlations.
The nine numbers (0-9) used in the Pythagorean system of numerology, representing the nine Monads (basic manifestations of the Goddess) that form the spiritual essence of the universe.
Double-digit numbers (11, 22, 33, etc.) in Numerology that hold greater significance and meaning than their single-digit reduction, indicating heightened spiritual or practical potential.
The Pagan concept of the afterlife or spirit realm, described as a pleasant place of peace, joy, and continued spiritual activity where souls go between incarnations.
Advanced spirits, often Beloved Ancestors or 'Guardian Angels,' who assist living individuals in daily life and spiritual development, sometimes acting as World Walkers.

An adept who voluntarily crosses between the Earthly World and the Otherworld through trance or vision, often to communicate with spirits, help other spirits cross over, or facilitate conscious incarnations.
The process by which an adept's soul deliberately chooses to return in a suitable incarnation to continue its work or fulfill a multi-generational project, often aided by World Walkers.

A central concept in Pagan thought and sex magic, representing the ritual union of Goddess and God (Spirit and Matter), often enacted symbolically or literally for spiritual growth and channeling Divine energy.
In Hindu Tantra, the coiled serpent power located at the Root Chakra, which, when awakened, rises through the spine to unite with the Crown Chakra, leading to spiritual ecstasy and enlightenment.
Currents of Earth's energy, either Yang (straight, surface) or Yin (curvilinear, deep), used for dowsing, psychic development, and geometric magic, connecting ancient monuments and energy vortices.

The practice of using three-dimensional geometric forms (e.g., spheres, tetrahedrons, pyramids, cubes) as energy constructs, created through visualization and intent, to focus, shape, and project energy for magical workings, particularly with Ley Lines.

The eight sacred Trigrams in Chinese philosophy, fundamental to the Yi Jing, representing the inherent order of the universe and the interplay of Yin and Yang, characterized by natural phenomena and family roles.
Organizational structures within the Correllian Tradition; a Witan Shrine is a probationary temple, while a full Temple has attained seated status in the Witan Council.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a comprehensive practical system for Second Degree Correllian Wicca, integrating diverse esoteric traditions into a cohesive magical practice. It emphasizes daily spiritual exercises, the development of psychic abilities, and the application of metaphysical knowledge for personal growth, healing, and influence in the world. The system encourages hands-on engagement with various divinatory tools, energy working techniques, and the construction of magical constructs.
tools: Stones (Quartz Crystal, Lapis Lazuli, Amethyst, Moonstone, etc. for amplifying energy)
Silk and fine wooden boxes (for storing cards)
Slips of paper, wood, plaster, or stone with magical alphabet symbols (Runes, Ogham, Correllian letters)
Forked stick or copper dowsing rods
Yarrow wood sticks or coins (for Yi Jing)
The Ulunsuti (Eye of Uktena, for Crystal Web work in Correllian Mother Temple)
rituals: Tarot Readings (One Card, Three Card, Celtic Cross, Zodiac, Yes/No Spreads)
Ohm Exercise for cleansing and raising vibrational frequency, opening Throat Chakra, and lung capacity
Chakra Opening and Coloring (sequenced use of colored, white, purple, silver stellar, golden stellar, and amber light balls)
Personifying Chakras for direct communication, healing, and programming specific tasks
Projecting Light Beams from Chakras for manifestation, healing, drawing, and writing (e.g., from Solar Plexus, Root Chakra)
Working with Magical Alphabets for Gematria, spellwork, and creating magical atmosphere
Numerological analysis of names and birthdates (Base Number, Personality Number, Life-Path Number)
Divination with Correllian Alphabet (drawing letters, arranging in circle with pendulum)
Locating Ley Lines through dowsing (forked stick, copper rods, pendulum) and clairvoyance
Geometric Magic (visualization and construction of spheres, beams, tetrahedrons, pyramids, cubes, octahedrons, decahedrons, dodecahedrons, icosahedrons for energy work)
Yi Jing Hexagram Readings (using yarrow sticks or coins)
Conscious Manifestation Spells (with incantations and visualization, pulling abstract images into Crown Chakra)
Sending energy to spirits for crossing over or focusing for eventual return
Observing appropriate funereal ceremonies for closure and focus for future incarnation

relevant_quotes.text: The symbol of the Second Degree of Clergy is the Pentagram, the five pointed star facing upwards, which represents the union of the Spirit with the Four Elements.

Some believe that the Tarot contains within it all of the secrets of the Universe. That, correctly interpreted, the Tarot is a scripture –visual rather than written- which preserves ancient teachings of metaphysics handed down from the Platonic, Hermetic, and Pythagorean teachers of the Classical world. This is a view with which the Correllian Tradition is substantially in agreement.
Knowledge is like a muscle, the more you use it, the more it grows.

The Correllian Tradition takes the position that psychism and magic are not gifts that one is born with so much as skills which one develops. Granted one may be born with these skills fully developed –but this is only because the skills have already been built in previous lifetimes. The flowering of psychic abilities is the reward of effort –often a great deal of effort- and we feel that one is entitled to the fair reward of that effort: that is to say, reasonable payment.

In saying these things we do not mean to overwhelm you, or to imply that we expect a superhuman effort. We are all people –we all act foolishly or even badly sometimes, we all make mistakes. But by keeping these things in mind you will find that you can sometimes avoid pitfalls that others before you have made.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book serves as a foundational text for Second Degree Correllian Wicca, providing a comprehensive and practical curriculum that synthesizes a wide array of esoteric and occult traditions. Its value lies in offering a structured approach to metaphysical development, integrating historical context with operative techniques. The emphasis on personal spiritual growth, ethical conduct, and community interaction positions it as a relevant guide for modern magical practitioners seeking a well-rounded and actionable framework.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is Second Degree Clergy within the Correllian Tradition, as it explicitly builds upon First Degree lessons and aims to equip them with advanced practical and theoretical metaphysical skills. However, its broad scope and detailed explanations of various occult systems (Tarot, Astrology, Numerology, Physiognomy, Chakras, Ley Lines, Magical Alphabets, Sex Magic, Calendrical Astrology) also make it highly relevant for any serious student of Western Esotericism, Occultism, or modern Paganism who seeks an in-depth, structured, and practical understanding of these subjects.
